author: @azazel-776
text: Bias is an additional parameter associated with each neuron in the neural network. It serves as an offset or baseline value that helps neurons activate (produce output) even when the input values are all zero. In simple terms, think of bias as a measure of how easy it is for a neuron to activate or fire. It allows a neuron to be responsive to inputs even if they are not very large. Without bias, the neuron might not activate unless the inputs are significantly large. The bias term adds flexibility to the model. It helps the neural network account for situations where certain inputs might not be as informative but still play a role in making a prediction.

author: @azazel-776
text: Larger Weights: A larger weight means that the associated input feature has a stronger influence on the neuron's output. It essentially amplifies the importance of that feature in the neuron's decision-making process.  Smaller Weights: A smaller weight reduces the impact of the associated input feature on the neuron's output.

text: You can't have a neural network with biases only, because the output of the neuron would always only be whatever the bias is, and any change in the input would not change the output. In fact, you'd have to completely rely on backpropagation to do the job of the weights for you, so you'd essentially need to re-train the network for every single observation, and then it can only model that observation.  Imagine trying to model any curved surface using only horizontal lines that you can shift up or down.

text: @sentdex The np.dot function takes about 50 microseconds to complete on my machine but a slightly modified version of your for loop method is 2x as fast and can complete the same operation in only 25 microseconds. It turns out that adding biases to the np.array of layer outputs takes longer than just adding each bias to the neuron output before you append because you end up running two for loops so this dot function would be a lot more efficient. Here is the function:  def dot(iterator, multiplier, biases, layer_outputs=[]):     for neuron_bias, neuron_weights in zip(biases, weights):         neuron_output = 0         for neuron_inputs, input_weights in zip(inputs, neuron_weights):             neuron_output += neuron_inputs*input_weights         layer_outputs.append(neuron_output+neuron_bias)     return np.array(layer_outputs)     layer_outputs = dot(weights, inputs, biases)
